content.$t: Currently we pass Shill technology strings directly as ONC values. We should translate them to ONC strings.

title.$t: WebSockets in WebView dropping/hanging (but not explicitly disconnecting) after a couple minutes or on switching app

content.$t: Device name: HTC one M8 Android version: 5.0 WebView version (from system settings -> Apps -> Android System WebView): 37 Application: websocket chat Application version: alpha Expected result: I have a web app that runs on websockets (SockJS) talking to a python backend. It works flawlessy in the browser (on a computer, or my phone); socket connections stay open and useful allowing for messages to be sent and received as long as the window is open/active. If you leave the window for a while the socket may disconnect, but upon returning it will promptly reconnect and load what was missed. Actual result: I have cooked up a simple WebView for android which has no problem displaying the page and running the necessary javascript. Upon opening the app messages flow back and forth from client to server as expected, but then after a couple of minutes, the client keeps sending messages but receives nothing in return... It seems like the connection is being dropped but that the WebView is unaware that it has ended. Once in a while XHR long-polling randomly kicks in (the fall back for socket connections) and then drops out. Over all, the WebView's performance with WebSockets in my case is rather inconsistent/unreliable and I'm unsure if this is something that can be over come. Relevant code can be found here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/29241105/android-webview-chromeclient-sockets-dropping-connections-using-xhr-falback

title.$t: kMediaDrmEnableNonCompositing should not be enabled for WebView-based browsers

content.$t:
Currently, AwMainDelegate::BasicStartupComplete() appends the kMediaDrmEnableNonCompositing switch. In addition to enabling this functionality in dedicated WebView-based apps, it enables this mode in WebView-based browsers.

Currently, this breaks EME in such browsers because of issue 470275.

Even if that were addressed, it does not make sense to enable this functionality and/or video hole by default (and thus in WebView-based browsers) if Chromium/Chrome does not use it (due to UX concerns).

I think the best solution is to default both settings (or the one remaining after issue 470275 is resolved) to disabled and letting WebView-based apps opt-in.

title.$t: kMediaDrmEnableNonCompositing should not be set without use_video_overlay_for_embedded_encrypted_video

content.$t:
Currently, AwMainDelegate::BasicStartupComplete() appends the kMediaDrmEnableNonCompositing switch. (In Chromium, it can be enabled via a flag.) cast_browser_main_parts.cc also adds it on Android.

This causes a secure surface to be used for encrypted videos (EME). Without hole-punching, these videos do not render. (Prior to fixing issue 459416, the fullscreen was forced, which worked until the user exited fullscreen.)

If the use_video_overlay_for_embedded_encrypted_video renderer preference is set to true, hole punching is used and the video displays correctly.

Since kMediaDrmEnableNonCompositing only works with use_video_overlay_for_embedded_encrypted_video and use_video_overlay_for_embedded_encrypted_video only applies when kMediaDrmEnableNonCompositing is specified (right?), we should ensure they are always set together.

As long as hole-punching is only supported in WebView (issue 469348), we should just combine them. This eliminates a switch in favor of an existing preference. In other words, enabling video overlay for encrypted video also enables the secure surface path.

title.$t: Need better Chrome-exposed versioning system for telemetry features

content.$t:
When adding new telemetry features, it's important to gate their availability based on compatibility with the targeted browser.

One approach here is to use the Chrome branch number as exposed by DevToolsClientBackend.GetChromeBranchNumber. However, ContentShell lacks such a version number (as reported by the content::ContentClient::GetProduct() implementation), making the branch version (in its current form) problematic for such usage.

Perhaps we need a more flexibile way of versioning/exposing Chrome features as consumed by telemetry? Or maybe we already expose the necessary bits from Chrome (and its shells) and we just need to hook them up to telemetry?

title.$t: Ensure property trees don't regress performance.

content.$t: In order to switch from CalculateDrawProperties on the main thread, we must ensure that, in addition to producing correct results, we don't regress performance.

title.$t: Remove VIDEO_HOLE code after all platforms migrate to Ozone hardware overlay/underlay mechanism

content.$t: Ozone has implemented support for hardware overlays/underlays (issue 370522) in a way that minimizes the impact on the rest of Chromium. All existing users of VIDEO_HOLE should migrate to this mechanism (issue 469374, issue 470261). Once that is done, we can remove the VIDEO_HOLE code.

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. launch google-chrome-beta (42) or google-chrome-unstable (43) using "--kiosk" switch on command-line.
2. Visually inspect the resulting Chrome window.

What is the expected behavior?
In previous versions of Chrome, all UI was hidden and the window was fullscreen.

What went wrong?

Did this work before? Yes Chrome 41

title.$t: Convert networkingPrivate to IDL format with types

content.$t: Maintaining networkingPrivate in the .json format is rather painful. Also, we would like to add types to networkingPrivate which is much easier to do in the IDL format.

title.$t: Android: Replace use of VIDEO_HOLE with Ozone hardware overlay/underlay mechanism

content.$t:
Ozone has implemented support for hardware overlays/underlays (issue 370522) in a way that minimizes the impact on the rest of Chromium. We should add support for this mechanism on Android and stop using VIDEO_HOLE.

Like VIDEO_HOLE, this primarily applies to WebView, but the new mechanism might also allow us to consider it for the browser as well.

VIDEO_HOLE is currently used to enable use of the secure surface. Since most hardware does not currently support a secure texture mechanism, we would not be able to fall back to textures in such use cases.

However, once this is implemented, we may be able to consider also enabling a video surface for clear content in certain conditions. This would enable us to leverage the benefits of a video surface, but we'd need to ensure the experience does not degrade. In this case, fall back to using a texture (the current implementation) would be possible, though it is unclear if that can be done seamlessly.

title.$t: Erratic mouseenter/mouseleave events

content.$t:
On certain mouse events, chrome sends too many/too few mouseenter/mouseleave events, breaking the enter-vs-leave pairing assumption. Here is a really bad case:

1. Go to http://jsbin.com/cenoje/quiet .
2. Click-and-hold on yellow.
3. Drag to any other color.

Expected:
We shouldn't see yellow mouseenter's (expect possibly the very first one, depends on past mouse position).

Actual:
We see many yellow mouseenter's in a row, perhaps one-per-mousemove.


Other actions that could potentially trigger this behavior include:
- Context menu popup (I could repro once)
- Frame resizing (unverified).

In fact, this should happen whenever EventHandler::dispatchMouseEvent() is called with setUnder=false, because of the conditional update of m_lastNodeUnderMouse:
https://code.google.com/p/chromium/codesearch#chromium/src/third_party/WebKit/Source/core/page/EventHandler.cpp&l=1893

title.$t: TouchView Mode exits incorrectly

content.$t: Version: 43.0.2340.0 OS: Chrome OS What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Have device enter touch view mode. Having the keyboard be fully opened 360 degrees. 2. Hold device vertically in portrait mode. As close to level as possible. 3. Tilt the device left/right What is the expected output? What do you see instead? The device stays in touch view mode. Instead it exists, and re-enables. When the lid/base angle is 0 or 360, and vertical, it is difficult to tell the hinge angle apart. We currently give a buffer angle to prevent this, along with capping the accelerometer rate of change we allow before exiting. It appears that this is not tuned enough. Raw accelerometer data: Base: 102,123,-1004 Lid: -1028, -340, -46

title.$t: Compute property trees in Blink

content.$t: Currently, property trees are computed from cc::Layer properties in the main-thread cc code. Instead, we should compute the trees earlier in the pipeline in Blink, since doing so can be done more efficiently, and also Blink can reuse the trees for its own geometric computations.

title.$t: fractional-scroll-offset-fixed-position.html has an incorrect draw transform with property trees

content.$t:
fast/scrolling/fractional-scroll-offset-fixed-position.html (and its virtual test suite counterparts) has an incorrect draw transform for a fixed position layer when using property trees. There are at least two problems:
1) We ignore ScrollCompensationAdjustment. This code is being removed soon anyway, so might not be worth supporting.
2) Scroll snapping moves fixed position layers.

title.$t: transform-interpolation.html has incorrect draw transforms and visible rects with property trees

content.$t:
virtual/threaded/animations/interpolation/transform-interpolation.html has incorrect draw transforms and visible rects with property trees. The problems include:
1) Layers with univertible transforms shouldn't be skipped if transform is animating.
2) When computing visible rects, we need to use enclosing Rects rather than exact RectFs in order to match CDP.

There are also problems that seem to be caused by accumulating floating point error. We need to add sufficient tolerance to our comparisons with CDP.

title.$t: Updating Chrome Always at 0% Throughout the Entire Update Process

content.$t:
UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/43.0.2342.2 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. Go to chrome://chrome to perform automatic update
2. Look at the status message: "Updating Chrome 0%"
3. 

What is the expected behavior?
The "0%" should increase to "100%"

What went wrong?
It stays at 0% until the end of the update process. Then the status message says to restart chrome to finish the update process.

Did this work before? N/A 

Chrome version: 43.0.2342.2  Channel: dev
OS Version: 6.1 (Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2)
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 17.0 r0

The entire update process is successful, just the percentage stays at 0% and does not increase.

This has happened through many major versions of chrome. Although it is not a major bug, it is an inaccurate description of the update status.

title.$t: Chrome OS Login Screen Flickers on Load

content.$t:
Chrome OS Login Screen Flickers on Load

This happens because the <webview>'s container is display:none and so the <webview>'s BoundingClientRect is all zero. Thus, GuestView falls back to using a size of 300/300 and then resizes on attachment. This causes a bunch of flicker.

Disable Metro Mode Launch in Windows 10, until there some clarity on technical details for Windows 10 Platform.

title.$t: Can't recover with larger usb key

I was trying to do recovery (premp signed panther_moblab image) on my panther with a patriot memory supersonic 32gb key. The panther just beeped back at me.

I tried again with a smaller 4gb sandisk cruzer key and the problem went away and recovery worked.

content.$t:
Chrome: 42.0.2305.2 dev-channel clapper

When tapping to compose a new message in Inbox (using the red "+" button), the VK appears and occludes the text region for the message body, making it impossible to compose a message.

Possibly unrelated note: pressing the VK's enter key while the message subject line has text focus causes the underlying page to scroll.

title.$t: Remove uses of ImageBuffer from non-canvas code

content.$t: This will allow ImageBuffer to not have to worry about other clients and simplify its implementation complexity. Since all non-canvas uses are very simple, this should also make the other users less complex as well.

title.$t: gn: bad string value quoting

content.$t:
print(["\\\$ok", "\\one\\", "\\\\two\\\\", "\\\\\\three\\\\\\"])

outputs

["\\\$ok", "\one\", "\\two\\", "\\\three\\\"]

The first one is correct, but the rest are all wrong in one way or another.  The "one" and "three" are even syntax errors because they have a trailing backslash that will be parsed as escaping the ending quote mark.

title.$t: ARC: Add mouse hiding feature for kiosk / fullscreen

content.$t:
Some apps (like digital signage) want to be able to hide the mouse cursor.  This makes more sense when the app is in kiosk or fullscreen mode.

On Android, the behavior is to hide the mouse cursor after 2 seconds of inactivity, this may actually make sense if it's possible to mouse capture and/or hide the mouse in this window, and restore it, so that users can still interact with apps to configure them, but the mouse cursor can still hide.

title.$t: Samsung Chromebook hangs with exynos fence patch

content.$t:
When https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/#/c/253932/ is applied to daisy, having multiple pending frames hangs the device when opening a second tab.

Looks like the drive thinks we are rendering into the front buffer. I suspect this may be related to the partial swap lock up issue and frame-buffer bindings.

title.$t: Collect metrics for window snapping in Ash

content.$t: Collect metrics to determine the frequency of window snapping in Ash. We already have user actions to determine use of the snapping accelerator keys (Accel_Window_Snap_{Left,Right}), but not for snapping windows by mouse or touch.

title.$t: Browser hang when trying to display specific icon

content.$t: Chrome Version (from the about:version page): 43.0.2334.0 (Official Build) dev (64-bit) Is this the most recent version: It's the most recent dev channel but the bug is also reproducible in ToT local Chromium builds. OS + version: Ubuntu 14.04.1 LTS CPU architecture (32-bit / 64-bit): 64 bits Window manager: Unity URLs (if relevant): N/A Behavior in Linux Firefox: N/A Behavior in Windows Chrome (if you have access to it): Working as expected (Tested on most recent Canary) What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Launch google-chrome-unstable 2. Make sure #enable-new-avatar-menu is enabled 3. Sign in to chrome using a gmail account 4. Revoke Chrome's authorization for the account through accounts.google.com > Account Permissions 5. Open a new tab and wait a moment for sync to notice the auth error, the Avatar Button should show a yellow warning icon 6. Click on the Avatar Button to open the Avatar Menu and resolve the auth error What is the expected result? The Avatar Menu is shown, with a link to sign in again to Chrome. What happens instead? The Menu never appears and the browser becomes unresponsive. Please provide any additional information below. Attach a screenshot and backtrace if possible. I've tried to track down this issue because I initially thought it was a bug in the profile_chooser_view code but it now appears it may be somewhere else. Here's what I've found: - The culprit seems to be the warning icon displayed inside the Avatar Menu when there's an auth error as commenting the SetImage call here: https://code.google.com/p/chromium/codesearch#chromium/src/chrome/browser/ui/views/profiles/profile_chooser_view.cc&l=1218 or passing a default constructed gfx::ImageSkia instead of the icon fixes the hang. - The issue isn't reproducible on all machines but it happens 100% of the time on mine, both on dev channel and local chromium builds (debug and release). - There's no issue in the Beta channel so the issue is somewhere between 42.0.2311.50 and 43.0.2334.0 - The code laying out the menu completes properly and the hang seems to happen at the call to show the view here: https://code.google.com/p/chromium/codesearch#chromium/src/chrome/browser/ui/views/profiles/profile_chooser_view.cc&l=518 as commenting that out prevents a hang. sky@ I'm not sure where to send this bug, could you help me figure that out since it seems to require digging in views code? Thanks!

title.$t: 14 month validity EV certificates requiring 3 SCTs to get EV treatment

content.$t:
UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.10; rv:36.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/36.0

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. Visit a site with an EV certificate valid longer than 14 months but less than 15 months, with 2 valid SCTs from certificate transparency logs recognized by Chrome
2. You won't see the EV indicator

What is the expected behavior?
According to https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&pid=sites&srcid=ZGVmYXVsdGRvbWFpbnxjZXJ0aWZpY2F0ZXRyYW5zcGFyZW5jeXxneDo0ODhjNGRlOTIyMzYwNTcz certificates with validity length < 15 months should only require 2 SCTs.

What went wrong?
The date arithmetic logic of ApproximateMonthDifference() combined with HasRequiredNumberOfSCTs() (both in net/cert/cert_policy_enforcer.cc) doesn't match the spec.  ApproximateMonthDifference rounds "14 months and 1 day" up to 15 months, even though it's less than 15 months.  Then, HasRequiredNumberOfSCTs() checks if it's >= 15.  The simplest fix here would probably be to make that > 15 instead.  This would also be consistent with the other 2 length checks in the same function.

Did this work before? N/A 

Chrome version: Version 41.0.2272.104 (64-bit)  Channel: stable
OS Version: OS X 10.10
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 17.0 r0

title.$t: Devtools: search in console with 1000 messages is broken

The Accessible Name Property of the
Element should be Set to "\n"

content.$t:
The accName property of IAccessible should be set to a newline character when when the object is a <br> element. This matches Firefox's behavior. It's also the logical thing to do:
1. The accName property returns a short description of what the object is all about, so "\n" is appropriate.
2. <br. has the an accRole of ROLE_SYSTEM_WHITESPACE which is not specific enough to describe the <br> element, thus accName should also be set to something more descriptive.

title.$t: Cannot exit handwriting by tapping the keyboard icon if the privacy warning is at present

content.$t: Version: 43.0.2340.0 canary OS: Chrome What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Open the virtual keyboard on a TouchView device 2. Go into handwriting mode for the first time (so that you see the "Your input will be sent to Google..." message) 3. Try to exit handwriting mode What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Expected: there should be a "back" button you can tap to exit handwriting mode Actual: the only way to exit is to tap outside of the handwriting area Please use labels and text to provide additional information.

title.$t: DevTools: overlay is misplaced with page scale

content.$t:
1. Open DevTools, emulate Nexus 5 for page scale to apply.
2. Enable inspect mode, hover over elements.
3. Overlay is misplaced.

title.$t: Provide smooth transition between loading sign-in UI and sync page on the new Gaia flow.

content.$t: Version: 43.0.2344.0 6865.0.0 OS: Chrome OS What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Enable new Gaia Flow pressing Ctrl+Alt+Shift+W on any gaia screen. 2. Add a new user onto device 3. Observe What is the expected output? Smooth sign-in into session UI. What do you see instead? 'Loading' screens of different views are jumping. Compare the process for old gaia flow UI: https://drive.google.com/a/google.com/file/d/0B0Pq_70XQgc1R0tUUGJiVlJEODg/view?usp=sharing And new one: https://drive.google.com/a/google.com/file/d/0B0Pq_70XQgc1M1h6NVBEcE9iaFE/view?usp=sharing Looks like in the old flow same 'loading' screen are better aligned between each other.

title.$t: [REGRESSION] DevTools: no cursor in console

content.$t:
1. Open console.
2. Press "up", then "down".
3. Cursor is gone.

title.$t: Inaccurate touch target detection on Android

content.$t: Version: 40.0.2214.109 OS: Android 4.2.1 (Galaxy Nexus) What steps will reproduce the problem? On an Android mobile: 1. Open http://flights.google.com, create an arbitrary flight and save it (click the "Save" button in the "Save this itinerary" section at the bottom). 2. Click the "View saved itineraries" next to the "Save" button. 3. Next to the itinerary title (Departure - Arrival), see the three-dots button. Touch the button at the bottom dot. At this point, you will be navigated to the itinerary in the main Flights page, as if you had clicked the itinerary card below the header. This is reproducible at least on Galaxy Nexus and Nexus 5.

title.$t: Courgette may not detect invalid 32-bit ELFs in huge (>4Gb) files.

content.$t:
If courgette is patching file larger than 4Gb, it may not notice segments or sections wrap-arounds for 32-bit ELFs inside that huge file. This could result in a crash if we continue to work with such invalid ELF. 

This affects only 64-bit systems, since 32-bit systems can't patch 4Gb files.

title.$t: Google Japanese Input (for US keyboard) doesnt have a VK popup

content.$t:
1. Add "Google Japanese Input (for US keyboard)" from language settings
2. select "Google Japanese Input (for US keyboard)" as current input method
3. switch to TouchView mode and tap ominibox
4. no VK

expected:
VK comes up.

I am not familiar with Japanese IME. over to shu for triage.

title.$t: ManagedNetworkConfigurationHandler::RemoveConfiguration must not remove configs from policy.

content.$t:
Currently, RemoveConfiguration removes any configuration even if it came from policy.

Instead, it must respect policy and prevent such removal of managed configurations.

title.$t: CrOS file picker extremely slow to open for heavy usage

content.$t:
UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; CrOS armv7l 6680.64.0) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/41.0.2272.89 Safari/537.36
Platform: 6680.64.0 (Official Build) stable-channel nyan_big

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. collect a multitude of folders and files on your chromebook (Acer chromebook 13 in my case)
2. open any app that allows you to pick files from FS/GDrive
3. Open file picker by choosing "open file..." from menu of an app

What is the expected behavior?
File picker instantly opens at last location and is immediately available for clicking on files

What went wrong?
The thing that should be a simple "file picker" takes loads of time to load, then enumerate files, directories, links and external sources, then finally shows the files at "default" location, then after some time allows to click to desired pick location, preloading everything on the way in a noticeable lag, at last you may pick a file and click "Open"

Did this work before? No 

Chrome version: 41.0.2272.89  Channel: stable
OS Version: 6680.64.0
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 16.0 r0

On any modern OS file picking is an instant operation: you want a file, you do a CTRL-O, click and open. There is no need to enumerate everything you've got on your drive, and everything is pre-cached and not loaded and executed every each time you decide to pick another file (file picker is the OS feature, not an external app and thus should be immediately available at any time in memory, fully loaded)

title.$t: console.log of a function should behave like firebug

content.$t:
UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/41.0.2272.101 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce the problem:
1. define a function in a file .js, insert it in an .html page, open the page with the browser, open the developer tools
2. open the Console, type console.log(name_of_a_function)
3. see the output

What is the expected behavior?
I want to see a >clickable< string with the function signature (something like "function_name(name_of_arg1, name_of_arg2)"). Clicking on the string I want to "navigate" to the javascript file at the row of the function definition.

What went wrong?
I see the (totally irrelevant, IMHO) body of the function.

Did this work before? N/A 

Chrome version: 41.0.2272.101  Channel: beta
OS Version: 6.3
Flash Version: Shockwave Flash 17.0 r0

The behavior I suggest is the same as the firebug plugin for firefox does actually.

title.$t: Regression: 'Context menu' is misplaced on 'Sign in' page, when 'Devtools' opened in 'Toggle device mode'

content.$t: Chrome Version : 43.0.2342.2 (Official Build) 403b1bffb9ecb3e9bc2a8bca8ccbfbc6d6143a70-refs/branch-heads/2342@{#3} (32/ 64-bit) OS : All (Aero enabled) What steps will reproduce the problem? 1) Launch chrome, navigate to 'chrome://chrome-signin/?source=0' page. 2) Open devtools by shortcut key i.e 'F12' or in Mac 'cmd+opt+I'. 3) Click on 'Toggle device mode', right click on 'Email' or 'Password' or 'Sign in' button to open 'Context menu' and Observe the context menu. What is the expected result? After right click on Elements, 'Context menu' should be open next to the mouse pointer. What happens instead? After right click on Elements, 'Context menu' is misplaced. This is a Regression issue broken in 'M-40' and below is the bisect info. Narrow bisect info: https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+log/f86de2b19af08f63d50309a9222ee40c9fda4710..8c0647856e87d352765cd9754b9c088c7d3316a1?pretty=fuller&n=100 Suspecting r301130
